div1.p:
The Arabs say that one should not look a
gift horse in the mouth, and Christians
generally believed that blessings should be accepted in an humble and a grateful
spirit, wherefore it may seem ungracious to find any fault with so indubitable
a blessing as Governor Magoon's decree nationalizing the sanitation service of
the island. Yet, while the measure in its entirety is so very good, we can
not but question the wisdom (until we know why) of the clause providing that
the chief of sanitation and the members of the board shall be appointed by the
president for terms of four years.

This term of office coincides with the presidential incumbency, and therefore
it seems that the sanitary department is to be political in character and its of-
fices to be part of the political “pap” which a presidential candidate may hold
out as a contingent fee to his supporters.

Now, it seems to us that the department of sanitation should be as far
removed from politics as the judiciary, and after considerable pondering we find
ourselves unable to divine any reason for changing its personnel every four
years. Moreover, the decree expressly provides that the president may at any
time remove the chief of sanitation or any member of the board “for cause.” This
suggests that these officials should continue undisturbed in the discharge of
their duties so long as they properly discharge them, and there can scarcely be
any question but that one may grow old in the discharge of such duties, becom-
ing by experience each year more valuable and efficient. To make continuance
in such offices dependent upon the partisan possibilities occurring every four
years is diametrically opposed to the whole theory and practice of the civil ser-
vice system of which President Roosevelt, ever since he entered public life, has
been so consistent a champion. We confess, somewhat regretfully, that we are
not omniscient, and there may be some excellent reason for making tenure of
sanitary office dependent upon political, or rather party, exigencies, but we can
not find it, and would be grateful for enlightenment.

What seems to us another flaw in the decree is the perpetuation of the de-
partment of “Special Hygiene,” by incorporating it in the National Board of
Sanitation. Why not abolish it? The excuses for such legalizing of vice, on
the score that the public health is thereby protected, while always lacking ethi-
cally, have been proven by experience to be invalid, even from a hygienic stand-
point. Eminent physicians in Havana declare that the protection thus afforded
does not protect. If this be true, why longer disgrace the city by making it a
procurer, deriving income from the vilest of traffics?--No, not the city now, but
the Cuban republic, since sanitation has been made national. Surely, it is not
fitting that any part of the president's salary should be paid by fallen women
for the privilege of plying their trade.
